instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
This board has <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is pulsing, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL> as well.
It does'nt start in smc bypass mode.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V_SUS</SIGNAL> are all present.

Replaced Bios just in case and checked all 22 resistors.
Checked <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and they are ok

Water was near Bios, <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5800</CHIP>.
I don't know what to check anymore.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Did you try known good BIOS file, or just clean ME region?
Do you also get pulse at pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?
Try to reball SMC.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Yes I tried 100% known working bios coming right from a working board.

I do have pulse as well on pin3 <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

Will reflow/ultrasonic/reball smc and report back.
Thanks!

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
I give up on this one.
Reballed smc same, replaced it same again.
checked again <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and ultrasoniced the board.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Liquid damaged board  is not always easy to fix.
Could be crap under some BGA, trace, or ball cracked.
A simple corroded resistor can cause the same issue.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
You are so right.
After a fresh look this morning I found out an open trace on <SIGNAL>SPI_CS0_R_L</SIGNAL>,
<RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR> was not anymore linked with <RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR>. All other trace were fine, 
I had a test point still with gold color but  with a tiny corrosion on the begining of the trace, barely noticeable, This was enough to kill the machine.
As always, thanks 2Informaticos.
